results.content:
The instruction is solid and done at a good pace, and this would be a great training if the time were put in to make sure it's in order. Unfortunately, it's clear that nobody ever reviewed or walked back through this lecture after it was completed.  Because of this, portions of the lecture seem to come out of nowhere and/or are broken in its current state. Here are a few specific examples:

-In lecture 5, he discusses a .gitignore file for a project that's not created until a later lecture (node-express-basic), then reverts to the current project (node-basic) in lecture 6 without mentioning any of this.
-In lecture 13 the video recordings are out of order. He runs `git push heroku master` twice back to back, then commits changes in package.json that we haven't made or even discussed, then later edits said package.
-Lecture 14 literally starts mid-explanation with setting a variable for a default port.

It's got all the right information explained in an understandable way; it just needs a little TLC.

results.content:
This course is very good as an intro level - it explains the NodeJS in general.

Good starting point to know what NodeJS is about in the top level.

results.content:
This course is useful when you are starting off with Node and want to get a very basic understanding on how to get up and running, but it doesn't go into much detail or any advanced topics.

There are other courses being offered on Udemy which are much more useful than this one.
results.content_html:
This course is useful when you are starting off with Node and want to get a very basic understanding on how to get up and running, but it doesn't go into much detail or any advanced topics.

There are other courses being offered on Udemy which are much more useful than this one.

results.content:
As a beginner Node.js course, this course suffers from a few issues:

1) The examples are pretty basic, but the explanation of how each of the very few lines of code works and why they're needed is almost completely missing.

2) A fair amount of time is spent on setting up git and heroku, but neither is essential to learning node basics.  The git and heroku "getting started" tips would be a nice extra in a course with more Node material, but feels like a waste of time here.

3) The course itself is a bit of a mess with both whole videos and sections within individual videos out of order.

There are several intro/basic Node.js courses offered on Udemy.  I would recommend one of the other before this one.
results.content_html:
As a beginner Node.js course, this course suffers from a few issues:

1) The examples are pretty basic, but the explanation of how each of the very few lines of code works and why they're needed is almost completely missing.

2) A fair amount of time is spent on setting up git and heroku, but neither is essential to learning node basics. The git and heroku "getting started" tips would be a nice extra in a course with more Node material, but feels like a waste of time here.

3) The course itself is a bit of a mess with both whole videos and sections within individual videos out of order.

There are several intro/basic Node.js courses offered on Udemy. I would recommend one of the other before this one.

results.content: The instructor jumps between projects, some stuff suddenly is just there and never explained. All in all it seems as if the videos in this course have been taken from a more comprehensive course and just been shuffled together.
results.content_html: The instructor jumps between projects, some stuff suddenly is just there and never explained. All in all it seems as if the videos in this course have been taken from a more comprehensive course and just been shuffled together.

results.content: Very basic introduction, that can be quickly viewed in a short period of time. Best probably for someone who wants just a little knowledge of what Node is about and whether it might be something they want to learn more about.
results.content_html: Very basic introduction, that can be quickly viewed in a short period of time. Best probably for someone who wants just a little knowledge of what Node is about and whether it might be something they want to learn more about.

results.content:
The course has good information, but, as of early January 2015, the videos are kind of out of order.

As you are pursuing the course, you'll find unexplained leaps in the topic at hand where work has been done or concepts are being discussed (for instance, the video on gitignore being in section 3 whereas you don't setup the folder structure he's using until after video 2 in section 4, and the Jade video seem out of sequence (section 5) too, since this structure already exists in section 4).

Also on the Jade section, by the time you watch this video, since the Express videos come before this section, to actually do what the author recommends in the Jade video would break what you've done previously, since the Express version of the app.js is setup totally different. Kind of a PITA. So, I have to simply watch the Jade video, vs. following along.

It's worth the price of admission for some I suppose, but I really recommend that the instructor do some live user testing, sit with people pursuing the course for the first time, take notes on where they are confused, and rerecord the course videos. Plus, it looks dated to see anything but Yosemite anymore. Perhaps this is nitpicking...

Also, a "whole course" is a long way to go to only have constructed something that, at the end of the course, only outputs 'Hello World'. At the end of the course, the 'app' you build does literally not. one. thing. more. Read that again.

Yes, you push to Heroku in the course, but is that really more important for an Intro course than the app doing *anything*?

I really don't mean to be overcritical here, because I think the author's heart is in the right place on this series, but I'm pretty underwhelmed. If the author would like to contact me after making changes to the course, I'd be happy to update my review.

Also on the Jade section, by the time you watch this video, since the Express videos come before this section, to actually do what the author recommends in the Jade video would break what you've done previously, since the Express version of the app.js is setup totally different. Kind of a PITA. So, I have to simply watch the Jade video, vs. following along.

It's worth the price of admission for some I suppose, but I really recommend that the instructor do some live user testing, sit with people pursuing the course for the first time, take notes on where they are confused, and rerecord the course videos. Plus, it looks dated to see anything but Yosemite anymore. Perhaps this is nitpicking...

Also, a "whole course" is a long way to go to only have constructed something that, at the end of the course, only outputs 'Hello World'. At the end of the course, the 'app' you build does literally not. one. thing. more. Read that again.

Yes, you push to Heroku in the course, but is that really more important for an Intro course than the app doing *anything*?

I really don't mean to be overcritical here, because I think the author's heart is in the right place on this series, but I'm pretty underwhelmed. If the author would like to contact me after making changes to the course, I'd be happy to update my review.

results.content: This course is a good intro to node.js and is a great place for someone to start learning node. Might give this 5 stars instead of 4 after I complete the next class, Advanced Node.js Development.
